On Mon, 2004-04-05 at 12:52, Chris Dollin wrote:
> On Friday 02 April 2004 23:09, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > mcgqa wrote:
> 
> > >      */
> > >     public void testRegisterUser() {
> > >                dupLoginId = newLoginId;
> 
> [both variables are Strings]
> 
> > This line is probably wrong. I assume you want dupLoginId to be a
> > "snapshot" of newLoginId. Right now, they refer to the same physical
> > string, so a change through one reference will be seen through the
> > second reference. 
> 
> Strings are immutable, so I don't see that this can happen. What am I missing?

Sounds like you need to read up on references...

The simple version is that "ABC" may be living at slot A in memory.  You
then set your variable newLoginId to equal that, which is to say that
there is some slot in memory (let's call it B) that now points to A. 
Then you set your dupLoginId variable that lives at slot C in memory and
tell it to point to slot B, which is pointing to slot A which is "ABC". 
Yes, strings are immutable, but that means nothing in this case.  You
have 2 references to the same object in memory.

-- 
Jason Rogers
